mainText: Addy Osmani published a post a while ago explaining their Netflix web performance case study. He explains the steps they've taken to improve the page load speed, and how they discovered opportunities to improve their Time-to-Interactive by keeping a close eye on the cost of JavaScript. Visit yas.fyi/2FBfKrf for more information.

The state of JavaScript survey 2018 is now published. They've collected data from over 20,000 developers, asking them questions on topics ranging from front-end frameworks to testing libraries and more. There are some very interesting stats in there with ES6 taking a lead in JavaScript flavours, and React being the lead in frameworks category. Visit 2018.stateofjs.com to explore more.

Goodbye Electron, Hello Desktop PWAs. A recent Chrome version(v70) has released some exciting support for Desktop Progressive Web Applications on Linux and Windows. Twitter, Starbucks and Google Maps have already invested in this a lot and are leading the way. For more info visit yas.fyi/2DEoAlt

Evan You previewed Vue 3 this week during his keynote talk at Vue Toronto. We can expect Vue 3 to be faster, smaller, more maintainable, more native friendly, and easier to use. To see his full talk on YouTube go to yas.fyi/2SaACar

Asynchronous processing in JavaScript traditionally had a reputation for not being particularly fast. Maya Lekova and Benedikt Meurer published an articale where they explain how they optimized async functions and promises in V8 (and to some extent in other JavaScript engines as well). Go to v8.dev/blog for more info.
